reviewText: The Anderson Tapes, 1972 filmThe story begins in a prison where inmates are being questioned. Some are released. Cameras record everyone's activities. [This predicted the future we know today - big government is watching you.] Duke Anderson goes to an apartment house to meet a woman after ten years. Who is watching him? Ingrid knows which tenants are loaded. Duke wants to get financing for his operation from a "businessman". [He can't use a bank.] The conversations carry the story forward. A judge approves wire tapping of an antique store (they distribute fake antiques). Tommy will provide about the target. Duke needs an electrician to disable the alarms. The state narcotics commission is watching him. Duke wants a driver, but he wants a percentage not a flat fee.Three men enter the apartment building to reconnoiter the place. [Note how each are treated by the watchman.] There is funeral. The IRS plants a bug on a car. "A lot has happened over the last ten years." Do they want to get involved in a crime when things are doing so well? Does the nurse carry a bugging device? Duke will get financing but he has to perform a task, and hires Morelli. There is a place in Harlem where they all meet. There is a conflict with Werner, Ingrid's boyfriend. A moving van is used to transport a smaller van. [Product placement?] Scenes of Manhattan without traffic? The robbery begins as a well-planned operation. Their uniforms make them look legitimate. A laundry cart transports their loot. One man uses a nickname. There is humor in some of the victim's response.What if there is a communications device in one room? Will the police take a collect call? Police cars surround the building. They will drop down from an adjacent building. Grappling hooks allow policemen to get onto the roof. Will the robbers hear this noise? They notice the lack of traffic in the street. "Look out, the truck is moving!" Will something go wrong? "Book `em" says the Captain. Will one robber hide from the police? The wounded are taken away by the officials. Those recordings are illegal, they are all erased so no evidence remains. [Isn't that "obstruction of justice"?] The good guys win again.This movie was adapted from a novel by Lawrence Sanders. The book is probably better. Are some of the words used now "politically incorrect"? There were other movies about a Big Knockover (a short story by Dashiell Hammett). "The Asphalt Jungle" and "Goodfellas" were better. This story seems to be a little too slow-moving.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Okay, okay I have beaten the old saw about Willie Sutton, the legendary old time bank robber, and his response to the question of why he robbed banks to death in reviewing a string of robbery films to death (The Ocean trilogy and The Thomas Crown Affair make and re-make). For the clueless old Willie’s response was “that was where the money was.” That same principle applies to the film under review, Sean Connery’s The Andersen Tapes, except Duke Andersen’s burglary bailiwick extended beyond banks to casing plush upscale Upper East Side New York City residences. Going where the fence friendly valuables were.Let’s set the scene. Duke, a career burglary, freshly sprung from a stir after doing a dime for some ill-disposed mistake decided the minute he got out to go back into business. He had a plan, had an inside take on the job (his kept woman girlfriend resided there), had some guys lined up and all he needed was a little seed money to put the operation together. Of course fresh out of stir guys are not good collateral risks to lend to for banks so he has to go to “the man,” the fixer man, to see if he could raise some kale. What he/the fixer man did not know was that the coppers, state and feds, were listening in to the fixer man’s conversations (and those of others too) and so they are vaguely but definitely aware that some high-end caper will be going down.Of course all Duke cares about from his end is getting back on easy street with one big caper pay-out so he can “pay the freight “ for his kept woman girlfriend (played by Dyan Cannon). And by his lights the thing went well for a while, he got his seed money, hired who he needed to hire, they cased the joint, set the date and moved out and pulled it off-mostly. Except technology and not even high technology got the best of the operation. So jerk kid used his ham radio network to snitch to the cops. So, no, Duke, will not be sitting on easy street with his honey anytime soon. Nor will his confederates.

reviewText: I first saw this film in a local theater when I turned fourteen. This forgotten gem was even more exciting when I recently watched this VHS with some friends. If you love cat and mouse intrigue with twists and turns, you'll love this movie. It features several major stars and a very young Christopher Walken. The FBI, mob, ex cons, and comical condo residents all make for some great entertainment. Recommended for mature teens and adults.
summary: "Anderson Tapes" Is a Tense Crime Drama Thriller

reviewText: I'm a big fan of director Sidney Lumet, particularly of his work from the '60s and '70s ('12 Angry Men,' 'Long Day's Journey,' 'The Hill,' 'The Pawnbroker,' 'Serpico,' 'Orient Express,' 'Dog Day Afternoon,' and his masterpiece, 'Network,' among others), but I find 'Anderson Tapes' clunky, dated and generally missing the point.  As a caper film, it's poorly constructed and maladroitly edited.  There is no real effort made to set up the logistics of the robbery or establish the characters of the quirky group involved, and that lack of groundwork renders the heist itself, which is badly executed and ultimately botched, barely interesting to watch and almost entirely devoid of suspense.  Now, that could be forgiven in the context of what should have been the larger satirical message of the movie:  the inability of the various 'big brother' entities-- which paradoxically rely upon their impressive techno-toys in lieu of good detective or communications work-- eavesdropping on the planning of the proceedings to connect the dots and foil the nefarious plot (sound familiar?).  However, this clever thematic thread is dropped halfway through and gets picked up again only as an ending joke, leaving the audience with rather an unsatisfied feeling.  Connery, looking prematurely shopworn, is OK but not utilized to any great effect; Walken is very good but underdeveloped; and Dyan Cannon seems to have been thrown in for no particular reason save a minor plot device (and some skin).  I even found Quincy Jones's score intrusive and out of place.  As another reviewer points out, the highlight of the film are the excellent glimpses of 1970s NYC.  I'm being generous in giving it three stars.

reviewText: Holy Christ is what I was thinking during Dyan Cannon and Sean Connery's scenes together.  I can see why this movie still has fans despite it being a 70s film.  It has authentic and unattainable New York real estate as the setting and a cast of residents who could have been understudies for the neighbors in Rosemary's Baby.  Everybody is VERY weird in that 70s weird and the decor is astonishing.  I'm sure if Aliens visited us during the 70s, they turned back around shaking their heads.Omigod,  Christopher Walken actually looks angelic but still disturbing.  Somehow his weirdness takes the edge off of how perfect looking his natural looks are.I can't believe any one let alone multiple agencies would bother with a thief like Sean Connery but that's how the movie gets its title - the Scotsman is under surveillance.
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Anderson Tapes" could have been a much better movie.  From reading the back of the box in the rental store and the promise of the all-star cast, I really thought I would enjoy this film more than I did.  The interesting story about a crime that is allowed to escalate despite the government's complete knowledge (due to the entanglements of government agencies and the monitoring) could have made for a great film.  But the pace of the film and the poor script really drag the whole project down.  In fact, I see that they are planning on remaking the film in 2005.  I will be interested to see what they decide to do to the film.The pace of Sidney Lumet's film is quite slow and the acting is sub-par.  Despite the fact that the film introduces a young Christopher Walken, he hardly speaks at all (which, in my opinion, is the whole reason you want Walken on the screen in the first place).  The ending is quite spectacular and unique, which makes up for some of the film that comes before it.  Also, I really enjoyed the way the director shot the film out of sequence, splicing the actual events with later footage of police interviews.  We keep seeing body bags moving in the background, but we have no idea who is in them.  I really enjoyed this technique and it helped to hold my interest.I imagine that if the remake gets produced that everyone will flock to see the original.  But in this case, and I say this very rarely, I hope and believe that the new version will be better.  Hopefully, it will follow the monitoring/tapes/government angle of the story and not forget about the intrigue it can add to the plot.
summary: Interesting Setup and Promise: Does Not Deliver
Title: N/A

reviewText: "The Anderson Tapes" is loaded with the sort of richness that you can count on when its director, Sidney Lumet is at the helm.  Sean Connery heads up the sort of first-rate cast of character actors that routinely gravitate toward any Lumet film. There is the sprinkling of humor and the rising suspense that you might expect from a movie about a plot to commit a robbery.  The director's masterful touch with pacing keeps the picture moving in a thoroughly engrossing fashion.  Most of all, his gift for drawing intense and powerful performances from his casts is in full flower here.  Screen the recent Lumet film, "Before the Devil Knows You're Dead" and you will see an even more intense and infinitely darker "caper-flick" that is, likewise, very worthwhile.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Director Sidney Lumet is impeccable in handling any type of material.  What should have been a routine caper film in the hands of Lumet's masterful direction and scenarist Frank Pierson (Oscar for "Dog Day Afternoon" turns into something transcendant.  Lumet isn't so much concerned with the caper because it's pretty routine and it's a foregone conclusion how it's going to go down.  What distinguishes the film is the terrific dark comedy and great characters.  What can you say about a movie whose cast includes everyone from Margaret Hamilton ("The Wizard of Oz") to Garrett Morris("Saturday Night Live")?  I particularly liked the work of Judith Lowry whose claim to fame was playing brassy grannies on Seventies sitcoms and plays a similar character here to great effect.  Sean Connery is ostensible star but basically his job is to be ringmaster to the circus environment.  A real gem and a feather in the cap for director Lumet.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Duke Anderson (Sean Connery) is a thief who has just be released from prison. His first thought as soon as he gets out is planning a big robbery, so he looks up some of his old comrades to get them to join him in the caper. First is shady antique dealer Tommy Haskins (Martin Balsam) who minces his way brilliantly through the film. The inspiration for the robbery is Anderson's girlfriend Ingrid (Dyan Cannon) who lives in an apartment building full of rich tenants with much loot that Anderson would like to get hold of. What Anderson doesn't realise is that many US law-enforcement agencies have several of his potential cronies already under surveillance - customs, FBI, the fraud squad, and others. So every move that Anderson plans to make is actually recorded from the outset. Nobody acts on it however because there are no warrants for these wire taps - they are all illegal. It takes a small bedridden boy in one of the apartments to alert the outside world about the robbery on his short-wave radio. The film is quite tense, witty and thoroughly entertaining.
summary: A robbery caper with Sean Connery as villain
Title: N/A

reviewText: Beautifully made caper film by one of the best in his prime, Sydney Lumet. The pacing and balance may be the true art of the film. Premise is a bit far fetched: recently released con (Sean Connery) plans extravagant heist  of entire Manhattan apartment building using mob financing. The hitch is  that most everywhere he goes during his planning, electronic surveillance  follows from varied and sundry sources.A young Chris Walken heads a  superb support group including Dyan Cannon. Martin Balsam is absolutely  spectacular as the femme antique dealer.Slightly dated, but never  tired, the story progresses like a time bomb countdown.Often imitated,  rarely duplicated.
summary: Great film that sometimes may get overlooked.

reviewText: Sean really seems to relish his role as a tough-guy ex-con in this intense caper from the early 70s that holds up nicely.  The conceit that everything we're seeing and hearing is culled from various surveillance tapes is a little distracting and doesn't quite work.  But Lumet's brisk, no-nonsense take on the action when the heist goes live still delivers.  Good NYC locations and Qunicy Jones jazzy score help.  The punch card type of the credits and those awful "futuristic" sounding, echoing computer beeps on the soundtrack  are what make the picture seem much more dated than it is.  Plus Lumet's inclusion of more than a few gay caricatures.It's fun to see Chris Walken's debut and Dyan is sensationally sexy. Only Alan King's irritating over-acting mars the cast.

reviewText: If you're not a fan of political correctness, and I'm not, you will love this thing. haw haw hawSubtle and bleak look at the future of surveillance and Big Brother. Sean Connery does 10 years in the joint, gets out on the same day with Christopher Walken, finds his ex girlfriend who lives rent free in an exclusive Manhattan apartment building, takes care of bidness, then while walking around in Dyan Cannon's robe (minus most of his hair), decides to rob the building.Great ensemble cast including Martin Balsam as a hilarious gay "decorator" who helps case the joint, and Garret Morris of Saturday Nite Live fame in an even more bizarre role as a police sergeant given the task of rappelling across the street with a makeshift SWAT team to rescue the building from Connery and his makeshift crew of crooks. Outstanding story that is totally marred by the annoying soundtrack and the constant reminder that "you are being watched!" Stupid tones and chimes galore with shots of video cameras everywhere and FBI all over the place recording phone calls and sexual this and that between Connery and Dyan Cannon who looks terrific, just wish we'd seen more of her and that body!I'd never heard of this flick before and now I understand why. Some excellent moments and performances that just get overridden by this goofy insertion of futuristic ding-donging that seemingly never ends, but I know what Lumet was going for. They even used the same font on the credits you will find on James Caan's Rollerball and Logan's Run. You know that computer generated font that everybody in Hollywood thought was going to be used in the year 2100? Anyway, its worth checking out, just don't expect to be blown away. 3 Safes
summary: "When you rob a guy who's got insurance, you're doing him a favor."

reviewText: Sometimes prison simply doesn't rehabilitate a man. One such lost cause is "Duke" Anderson (Sean Connery) who just got done serving a ten-year sentence. No sooner does he get out of stir than he starts scheming his next heist. This time he plots to burgle all the units in his girlfriend's (Dyan Cannon) luxurious New York apartment complex. In time-honored caper fashion, he recruits his crew, each member an expert in their field. Tagging along is a sadistic enforcer that the mob boss what's financing Duke insists participate in the exercise. No, I'm sure the mean muscle won't screw things up for our boys.Unbeknownts to Duke, he's become the inadvertent subject of surveillance conducted by a host of alphabet government agencies: the FBI, investigating some black activists; the IRS, curious about Duke's mob connections; and the (pre-DEA) Bureau of Narcotics and Dangerous Drugs, targeting a drug dealer. Meanwhile, Duke's girlfriend's sleazy sugar daddy (yes, she's a kept woman) has contracted a private eye to bug her apartment. Maybe Duke should've listened to his financier's word of caution: "They got a new breed of cop. They're everywhere."Maybe you'll appreciate the film's poking fun at the workings (or lack of) of bureaucracy. It's intimated that, shockingly, none of these monitoring agencies even attempt to coordinate with each other. In fact, were they even aware of each other? I can picture the street lined up with one nondescript van after another, each a separate island of frenzied recording and wire-tapping.BeforeEnemy of the State (Special Edition Unrated Extended Cut)(1998) andThe Truman Show (Special Collector's Edition)(1998),The Bourne Ultimatum (Widescreen Edition)(2007), and before evenThe Conversation(1974), THE ANDERSON TAPES first explored the theme of modern surveillance, its pervasiveness, the paranoia it induces. Released on June 17, 1971, this film is prophetic in that the Watergate scandal would break open a year hence, to the day. Director Sydney Lumet must be some prescient mother.This is the second of the five Connery-Lumet collaborations, a partnership that spanned nearly 25 years (1965 to 1989). At this stage in his career, Connery needed to prove that he could deliver a box office hit without playing 007, and THE ANDERSON TAPES did the trick. He's excellent, and backed by a very capable supporting cast. Martin Balsam nearly steals the show as a gay antique dealer. Very early in his film career, Christopher Walken as "The Kid" already exhibits those Christopher Walken quirks. Dyan Cannon, in a minor role, still sort of breaks your heart, her character faced with choosing between her old ex-convict love and her sugar daddy and the cushy life he affords her. Red-blooded guys should note that 1971 finds Dyan Cannon in the prime of her hotness. Comedian Alan King is absolutely convincing as the ruthless mob boss. And for fans of old-timey Saturday Night Live, a fit Garrett Morris has a tiny pre-SNL role as one of the police officers tasked with infiltrating the apartment building, a feat that promised an immoderate amount of calisthenics. No, Morris isn't that one cop who hilariously has trouble scaling that one wall. Oh, yes, THE ANDERSON TAPES is also surprisingly funny.***Heads up: the last sentence of this next paragraph may contain a plot spoiler***If you like heist movies, THE ANDERSON TAPES won't disappoint. Yes, it looks dated, the technology is laughable compared to what we have nowadays. And it took me a bit to get used to the whirring and beeping electronic noises incorporated into the film's score. But the movie competently checks off the other boxes. The cast sells it as they go thru the process of casing the joint, executing the heist, and then coping with the inevitable snafus. I betcha Duke Anderson, should he get out of this mess, won't be so nice to a crippled kid next time.
summary: "They got a new breed of cop. They're everywhere."

reviewText: The Anderson Tapes conspicuously mentioned in this film's title are very peripheral to the film's plot. Instead we have a brilliant `caper film' set in a New York City townhouse in early 1971. The images are still memorable of a balding Sean Connery as the leader and brains behind the heist. And who can forget that stoic and peculiar looking member of Connery's team, Christopher Walken in his first film. What an impression he made. This film still looks current even today. This is a real suspenseful film full of great characterizations. A good one!

reviewText: This film should have been a lot better than it is, considering the quality of the cast and the reputation of the director. The problems are a good idea marred by a poor screenplay with generally lackluster dialog, unaccountably pedestrian direction, and a confusing mishandling of the surveillance motif which makes it hard for the viewer to understand properly how it fits into the rest of the film. Probably only two stars, but give it an extra star for the strong supporting performances, especially by Ralph Meeker and Alan King, and the excellent jazz soundtrack by Quincy Jones. Worth watching for those strengths.  Good DVD transfer.
summary: Has its strengths but overall disappointing

reviewText: I bought this on a lark just to see the reel to reels used in the film (I use them). I wasn't disappointed, but the movie was certainly not one of Connery's best. It's one of those movies that exploited current technology of its day, but looks ridiculously inept by today's standards. Any movie that jumps on the technology bandwagon will look dated in ten yrs-it's just a chance the producers take. It's definitely a walk down memory lane, but not any sort of defining moments in movie history fare.

reviewText: As thriller,"Anderson Tapes"is average. However as theater - an ensemble piece - it's an American classic.  Sean's best role: a likeable guy out of jail after staying quiet for ten years on behalf of the mob. They owe him a favor (small potatoes)which is the problem (they now prefer big business - linen service, construction, etc.).  Ultimately they stake Connery and his magnificent raggedy crew to pull a major burglary (Sean's retirement). Meanwhile the FBI (in search of bigger fish) monitors Connery's ensuing bad luck like an indifferent god.

reviewText: Sean Connery plays an ex-convict quick to organize a complicated burglary in his ritzy girlfriend's apartment building (Dyan Cannon). Unbeknown to Connery or the police, a third party is taping events throughout the apartment building.Permission to do the burglary is received from the local organized-crime figure but requires that he take along one of their men and that Connery kill him. What is more colorful is that Martin Balsam plays a faltering fag and Christopher Walken a safe cracker, both members of the gang. This is Christopher Walken's earliest known movie.All-in-all the film is solid entertaining and worth the price.

reviewText: I've watched this flick no less than 20 times in my life and just love the way Sidney Lumet directed this killer cast and captured New York in the 70's along with the jazz of Quincy Jones' soundtrack... it's just a hip flick! The surveillance and paranoia of the "tapes" is indicative of the 70's Watergate scandal and captures that moment in time-- and still relevant on some levels today. I'm glad to see it finally came out on DVD... also recommend reading Lawrence Sanders original book which the movie was based on and Sanders' seminal style in rendering this Pulpish tale.
summary: A CLASSIC HEIST  FINALLY SAFECRAKED FROM SONY'S VAULT

reviewText: At least, it doesn't pay for Duke Anderson (Sean Connery), a breezy and insanely over-confident burglar who has just got out from a 10-year hitch in the slammer.  Within 2 minutes of leaving prison, he and his protege 'the Kid' (Christopher Walken) try rolling an elderly fellow-convict.  What they don't know is that a new age has dawned in 1970s America: the age of surveillance - by security camera, tape recorder, time clock, phone bug, etc.  After talking his way out of this near-disaster, Duke heads over to a fancy Upper East Side residential building for a happy reunion with ultra-chick Ingrid (Dyan Cannon).  He immediately launches a plan to rob the entire building - with the assistance of a ragtag group of associates and the sponsorship of mob boss Angelo (Alan King).  Alas, all of these dubious characters are being trailed and bugged by various parties: the Feds, the NYC police, private investigators, etc.  The heist goes ahead but goes awry, with electronic technologies playing a key role.  Ultimately, the big-shot burglar is brought low by a young boy in a wheelchair - who happens to have a ham radio.The Anderson Tapes could not have been more timely.  If the functionaries of the Nixon administration had seen it, they might have saved themselves (and the country) a lot of grief.  It is also timely today; the only difference is that the tools of surveillance are now a thousand times more powerful.  I don't believe the film was a commercial hit, despite having big-name stars, a leading American director and a sure-fire topic (NYC crime).  Unlike The French Connection or The Seven-Ups, the story-telling unfolds in a slow, steady and methodical way -  more like an English crime drama.Apparently, the soundtrack is out of print.  I would call it 'early electronica' and it does lend a jaunty, good-humored atmosphere.Theme From "The Anderson Tapes"

reviewText: The Anderson Tapes is one of my favorite caper films from the early 1970's. The interesting cast alone is worth the price of admission - Dyan Cannon, Dick Anthony Williams, Alan King, Martin Balsam, and a very young Chris Walken as The Kid. But it's cool Sean Connery who is the glue guy holding it all together. And the gritty New York City background makes this native New Yorker homesick for 20-foot wide sidewalks.

reviewText: The Anderson Tapes is an example of what director Sidney Lumet is capable of creating: an entertaining yet somehow thoughtful film.  This was the movie that actually made me appreciate Sean Connery.  In the Bond films he was doomed to be typecast.  Sidney Lumet bailed him out and Connery owes him big time.  Great setup and cameos: including an underrated scene with the great Garret Morris as a limber police officer, who would go on to become one of the original Not Ready for Prime Time Players on Saturday Night Live just a few years later (along with Belushi, Chase, Radner, etc.).  Christopher Walken looks like a baby in this one and Martin Balsam is pretty funny.  Nice flash forward scenes make it seem like it can never be a dated film.  Chilling last scene makes the film and a point about our technological age.
summary: Warning-this is NOT a period piece

reviewText: Solid performances and director Sidney Lumet's New York atmosphere rescue a somewhat plodding pre-Watergate caper flick. Based on Lawrence Sanders' novel, "The Anderson Tapes" (1971) never catches fire until the last half-hour when the luxury-apartment heist finally takes flight. Sean Connery excels in his first non-Bond hit - displaying good chemistry with a young Christopher Walken.

Yeah being a fan of 007 , I saw it at the movies in Chicago ,and saw it again today and still liked it .

reviewText: Directed by Sidney Lumet, and based on a novel by Lawrence Sanders, The Anderson Tapes takes a look at the pervasiveness of surveillance, and the technical advances that make it possible.  Making the point, that what you think is secure, may not be.After just completing a ten year stretch behind bars, Robert "Dutch" Anderson takes up residence with his old girlfriend Ingrid Everleigh (Dyan Cannon), in her New York City luxury apartment building.  In a brilliant revelation, Dutch decides that her building would be the perfect place to rob, and begins to put together a team of criminals to do the job, unaware that various government agencies have some knowledge of his "secret" plans.While Anderson has been in prison, surveillance has become a very common tool for law enforcement.  Ingrid's apartment is bugged, and his pillow talk discussing the robbery is recorded on tape by a private investigator.  Anderson is captured on film when recruiting his prison buddy Kurt Spencer (Christopher Walken), nicknamed "the Kid", and also when meeting driver Edward Spencer (Dick Williams).  The IRS is listening, when Dutch has discussions with organized crime leader Pat Angelo (Alan King) about financing his caper.  Under suspicion for dealing in stolen goods, interior decorator Tommy Haskins (Martin Balsam) has his phones tapped by the police, when Dutch drops by to ask him to case the apartment building.Nobody is specifically after Anderson, and none of the various government agencies has enough information to piece together the whole scheme, so he is able to continue with his plans.  Ingrid's current beau Werner Gottlieb (Richard B. Schull) is aware of the planned robbery, but as long as he gets Ingrid back, he is willing to say nothing.  Angelo backs the operation, but with the condition that a man named Socks Parelli (Val Avery) join the team, and be assassinated during the robbery.  With few options, Anderson agrees, and the job is set up for the Labor Day weekend.  On the fateful day, a Mayflower moving truck pulls into the building, and the robbery begins, with Dutch's old prison buddy Pop Myer (Stan Gottlieb) replacing the regular doorman in the lobby, keeping an eye on a bank of security camera monitors.There are some faint glimmers of hope as the team cuts of phone service, and begins to working their way through the building.  Parelli gets a little too violent, but things seem to be going fairly well, until they enter a suite with a crippled boy.  Although apparently helpless, the youngster manages to get word to the police, who soon surround the building.The Anderson Tapes points out how advances in technology had made security harder to maintain, and that such power could easily be abused.  Given the quantum leaps that have been made in technology, this may seem very inconsequential now, but back when some computers executed programs on punch cards, this was a relatively new frontier.The Conversation(1974) was another film from the period about eavesdropping.  Taped conversations would soon bring down a President, so in some regards, The Anderson Tapes was on the cutting edge of current events.Breaking out of his role as James Bond 007, Sean Connery is terrific playing an intelligent tough guy, who is very much in control.  From being in prison, Dutch's understanding of things is a little behind the times, and his decision to rob the building he is staying at seems questionable, but otherwise his plan is nicely thought out and executed.  Dyan Cannon brings plenty of kittenish sex appeal, but unfortunately her character bows out early.  The supporting cast is extremely solid, with the criminals, tenants, and the police, featuring a nice blend of colorful characters.  As the Kid, Christopher Walken, does well in his film debut, and together with Gottlieb, and Balsam, provides Anderson with a memorable crew of criminal mates.  The police's special tactics team led by Garrett Morris (SNL), also performs with realistic professionalism.With some solid acting performances, The Anderson Tapes is an intelligent, hard-edged, and provocative thriller, with a cool jazzy score by Quincy Jones.  Even with the odds heavily stacked against him, Anderson might still have succeeded, or at least escaped capture, but the studio apparently insisted that the ill-fated scheme end in failure, preserving the film's downbeat cynical ending.
summary: the growing prevalence of surveillance is featured in this crime caper that predates Watergate...
Title: N/A

reviewText: Made in 1971 when Sean Connery was still unsuccessfully trying to find an audience outside of 007, Sidney Lumet's The Anderson Tapes is a playful heist thriller that managed to be just ahead of its time in its take on the surveillance society. Connery is the newly released burglar who comes up with a scheme to raid the high-rent apartment building his for rent girlfriend Dyan Cannon lives in, recruiting a gang including a magnificently pompadoured Martin Balsam's camp antiques dealer who clearly has a huge crush on him and a very young Christopher Walken, bankrolled by mobster Alan King on the condition that he takes along and kills one of his more troublesome soldiers during the heist. The twist is that every step of the way every single detail of the plan is taped by the Feds, the IRS, the police, private detectives and drug enforcement officials, all of whom are operating illegal wiretaps and none of whom are remotely interested in his scheme because they're either looking for something else or have bigger fish to fry. The prescience is underlined by one scene where the Feds discuss a tape while on the wall hangs a photo of one Richard M. Nixon, who would have his own problems with burglaries and incriminating tapes the following year...But there's more to Dog Day Afternoon writer Frank Pierson's screenplay and Lumet's direction than just the gimmick, both taking delight in undermining the various characters' pronouncements, be it Connery's philosophy on society's need for crime to function properly or King `seeking advice' from his silent and barely alive father when he's really just talking himself into backing the job: they don't really believe what they're saying, but they like to put on the show. The robbery itself is inventively undercut by being constantly punctuated by flash-forwards to the aftermath, a device that surprisingly manages to build up rather than detract from the tension. Connery's clearly having a field day playing someone who doesn't have a license to kill for a change, showing a different kind of charm and self-confidence along with the odd moment of uncertainty, and the ensemble cast provide excellent support (Ralph Meeker and Margaret Hamilton, in her last film, are in there as well). Quincy Jones' score occasionally overplays the heavy-handed electronic sound effects, but, along with one spectacularly unflattering close-up of Cannon, it's one of the few missteps in a caper movie that's surprisingly light on its feet.Columbias DVD offers a decent widescreen transfer with the trailer the only extra.
summary: A playful heist thriller that was ahead of its time

reviewText: ...are funny things. I hadn't seen this film since I was a teenager. I was a military brat living in Germany and going to the base theater was always a treat for me and my friends--a way to escape and get a bit of Americana. It's funny how I remember movies from that time period--I think I tend to get a lot of them jumbled up. I won't say I was totally disappointed but it wasn't as good as I had conjured it up to be in my mind from memory. Pretty standard 70's fair and at the price you can pick this up at it's well worth it if the movie peaks your interest even a little. If for nothing else than the cast--this is a very interesting mix. It kind of neat to see the young Chris Walken!
